Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Visar Ajeti of University of Wisconsin - Madison to conduct a research project, entitled "Microfabrication of extracellular matrix (ECM) at large scale," during the summer of 2012 at National Cheng-Kung University in Tainan, Taiwan. The host scientist is Dr. Shean-Jen Chen.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in understanding and applying cell-matrix interactions using highly mimetic ECM models. The proposed research explores implanting highly mimetic ECM structures in animal models to get a better understanding of cell-ECM interaction. These studies can be used not only to understand basic biological principles in model systems but also permit the development of tools and drugs that have higher sensitivity and applicability in vivo.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE The main focus of my research has been developing in vitro models of the extracellular matrix (ECM) using optical techniques to study invasion and metastasis of ovarian cancers. The microenvironment that surrounds the cells provides mechanical and signaling cues that play a vital role in cell migration, proliferation, differentiation and survival .Therefore having models that accurately mimic the environment at the micrometer scale is crucial in understanding the mechanics of cancer invasion and metastasis. The mimetic in vitro models we are generating are based on multiphoton excited photochemistry whereby ECM proteins are cross-linked at the focus of the laser beam. This is a powerful and enabling technique to generate free-form 3D protein structures by spatio-temporally manipulating the focus of the laser beam. The ECM nanofabrication system comprises of a Titanium Sapphire laser (for short pulsed laser), a microscope and scanning head. In order to generate ECM structures, we have written software that controls the scanning head and optics to appropriately manipulate the laser beam. This enables the user to generate any free-form 3D structures with desired ECM proteins (such as collagen, fibronectin and laminin). However, one of the main challenges we were facing was accurate communications of software to hardware. This was especially evident in attempts to fabricate structures at large scale (range of millimeters). As the result of the NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute award, I was able to visit Dr. Shean-Jen ChenÆs lab at National Cheng Kung University in Taiwan and solve some of these limiting steps in our fabrication system. One of the main objectives at Dr. ChenÆs lab was to correctly implement Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGA) and revamp the fabrication software. As a result, we were able to achieve close to real-time communication of software with our optical system. We also implemented an Electro Optical Modulator (EOM) – an optical device used to shutter the laser for each pixel that the pattern is scanned. Incorporating these two components allowed us to generate image-inspired 3D structures with high fidelity to the in vivo ECM. Figure 1a is an example of ovarian tissue imaged using Second Harmonic Generation (SHG) specific to collagen, while Figure 1b and 1c are the fabricated structures using the those SHG images as patterns of fabrication. We believe that this technique is an enabling component in the scientific community to generate highly mimetic ECM structures from image-inspired data. We have also made the software available on our website for other researchers interested in implementing this system in their lab settings. (http://campagnola.molbio.wisc.edu/) I am very thankful to the NSF EAPSI program for giving me this opportunity to travel to Taiwan and pursue this resarch. Participating in the EAPSI Taiwan program has added tremendous cultural wealth and sparked frutiful collaborations between our lab (Campagnola at UW-Madison) and Dr.ChenÆs lab in Taiwan. Our recent publication: V. Ajeti et al "Image-inspired 3D multiphoton excited fabrication of extracellular matrix structures by modulated raster scanning" on Optics Express is direct outcome to this positive experience. Last Modified: 11/27/2013 Submitted by: Visar Ajeti
